channel.title: Runescape "API" class

item.title: Runescape "API" class
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:24, topic:317553”]Found a good reason to use many functions instead of just one

[quote]get_stat(“Attack”, “level”): 4.5332193374634E-6
get_attack_level(): 3.1753301620483E-6[/quote][/quote]Those results are most likely spoofed, unless you implemented the generic function horridly. The eval() function should, in theory, take longer than simplistic conditional statements and array-index lookups. Regardless of this, the minute incremental benefit in time should not be used as the deciding factor in this case. It is obvious that it would be far more convenient to you and to the user implementing this ‘library’ if you would replace all the skill-specific function naming with a generic one.

As I recommended before, have constants for each skill referencing their index in the array, and have constants referencing indices for “rank”, “level” and “xp”, in order so that the generic function could be invoked as easily as:

get_stat(StatGrabber.ATTACK, StatGrabber.LEVEL)

Read full topic

[quote]get_stat(“Attack”, “level”): 4.5332193374634E-6
get_attack_level(): 3.1753301620483E-6[/quote][/quote]

Why would they ever return different results?

item.title: Runescape "API" class
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

[quote=“Graham, post:23, topic:317553”][quote author=ZeroFreeze link=topic=414066.msg3058776#msg3058776 date=1260701406]

eval("$this->get_{$_GET[‘skill’]}_level()");

or something along the lines of that, if you really wanted to. Obvious sanitisation is needed

That’s a really ugly way of doing it though.
[/quote]

And insecure.[/quote]
Which is why I said “Obvious sanitisation is needed”[br][br][size=1]Posted on: January 06, 2010, 12:47:05 pm[/size][hr]Found a good reason to use many functions instead of just one

get_stat("Attack", "level"): 4.5332193374634E-6 get_attack_level(): 3.1753301620483E-6

Read full topic

item.title: Runescape "API" class
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

[quote=“Wewt, post:15, topic:317553”][quote author=eczema3 link=topic=414066.msg3053997#msg3053997 date=1260311404]
I meant repetitive like this:

$rs->getStatInfo("Attack", "level"); $rs->getStatInfo("Strength", "level"); $rs->getStatInfo("Defence", "level"); $rs->getStatInfo("Prayer", "level"); ... etc
[/quote]

The problem with the method that you posted is that it’s almost impossible to actually use in any feasible instance. For example, I write a program using your “api” that allows a user to look up a specific stat for a RuneScape player. Problem with your function is that in order to print out, for example, the user’s attack level, i have to have a large switch statement like this:

<?
$skill = $_GET['skill];
switch($skill){
   case 'attack':
      get_attack_level();
   break;
   case 'defence':
      get_defence_level();
   break;
   case 'strength':
      get_strength_level();
   break;
etc etc etc.
}
?>

If you use the method I posted, you could just do this:

$this->getStatInfo($_GET['skill'],"level");

To me, that’s a lot easier and a lot more efficient. If you’re still wanting to design a RuneScape API, I’d suggest reading up on API design (http://lcsd05.cs.tamu.edu/slides/keynote.pdf, for example). It’ll help.[/quote]
eval("$this->get_{$_GET[‘skill’]}_level()");

or something along the lines of that, if you really wanted to. Obvious sanitisation is needed

Read full topic

item.title: Runescape "API" class
item.dc:creator: @Wewt Wewt
item.description:
@Wewt wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:10, topic:317553”]I meant repetitive like this:

$rs->getStatInfo("Attack", "level"); $rs->getStatInfo("Strength", "level"); $rs->getStatInfo("Defence", "level"); $rs->getStatInfo("Prayer", "level"); ... etc[/quote]

The problem with the method that you posted is that it’s almost impossible to actually use in any feasible instance. For example, I write a program using your “api” that allows a user to look up a specific stat for a RuneScape player. Problem with your function is that in order to print out, for example, the user’s attack level, i have to have a large switch statement like this:

<?
$skill = $_GET['skill];
switch($skill){
   case 'attack':
      get_attack_level();
   break;
   case 'defence':
      get_defence_level();
   break;
   case 'strength':
      get_strength_level();
   break;
etc etc etc.
}
?>

If you use the method I posted, you could just do this:

$this->getStatInfo($_GET['skill'],"level");

To me, that’s a lot easier and a lot more efficient. If you’re still wanting to design a RuneScape API, I’d suggest reading up on API design (http://lcsd05.cs.tamu.edu/slides/keynote.pdf, for example). It’ll help.

Read full topic

item.title: Runescape "API" class
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

I’d rather use one method, and pass arguments to it, than having one method for every stat. If the only difference between several methods is one argument, you make one method that requires arguments instead of (well, I guess the term applies here) hardcode the arguments.

Read full topic

item.title: Runescape "API" class
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:10, topic:317553”]I meant repetitive like this:

$rs->getStatInfo("Attack", "level"); $rs->getStatInfo("Strength", "level"); $rs->getStatInfo("Defence", "level"); $rs->getStatInfo("Prayer", "level"); ... etc[/quote]ITS A GENERIC METHOD, AND YES THAT IS BETTER THAN

$rs->get_attack_level(); $rs->get_strength_level(); $rs->get_defence_level(); $rs->get_prayer_level();

ps instead of passing strings for the stat definition, define constants and pass them through arguments

[quote=“abraham2119, post:4, topic:317553”][quote author=eczema3 link=topic=414066.msg3052570#msg3052570 date=1260196919]
Because this is designed to make things easier instead of having arguments to functions. Also IIRC PHP doesn’t allow you to use array_returning_function()[key]
[/quote]because having 2 arguments in a function makes the ‘api’ so much more complex…[/quote]and having over 100 methods is so much simpler
